metadata.title: Enhanced NOx removal performance of amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst by hydrogen pretreatment
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

Table 1 Samples Surface atomic concentration (%) Ce Cex+/(Ce3+ +Ce4+) (%) Ti O Ox/(Oα+Oβ) (%) Ce3+ Ce4+ Oα Oβ Ce-Ti 10.50 28.78 71.22 15.26 74.24 38.59 61.41 Ce-Ti/H 11.25 38.66 61.34 15.49 73.26 49.78 50.22 Enhanced NOx removal performance of amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst by hydrogen pretreatment Lemeng Yu Qin Zhong ⁎ Zhiyong Deng Shule Zhang School of Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, 210094, PR China School of Chemical Engineering Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Hydrogen pretreatment was processed on the amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst which notably enhanced its NH3-SCR performance. We concluded that 3-h and 400°C were the most suitable and efficient pretreatment conditions, whereas the NOx conversion rate was above 95% from 210°C to 360°C for such pretreated catalyst. XRD, PL, H2-TPR, XPS and Raman analyses found that the enhancement was attributed to the effects generated by the pretreatment: Ce4+ reduced to active Ce3+, the incerase of the oxygen vacancies, the chemisorbed oxygen, and the formation of superoxide ions. The NO adsorption oxidation capability, and the acid sites were also promoted by the pretreatment, which were favorable for the SCR reaction. The reaction among NO, O2 and NH3 on catalysts were studied by in-situ DRIFT. The adsorption of NH3 was dominant under the SCR reaction conditions The enhancement demonstrated good durability. The stability of catalyst under water vapor and sulfur dioxide were also tested. Keywords Ce-Ti Hydrogen Pretreatment NH3-SCR Amorphous 1 Introduction Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) generated from stationary and mobile sources is one of the major atmospheric pollutants nowadays and has contributed to many environmental problems such as acid rain, photochemical smog and ozone hole [1]. This leads to stringent environmental regulations for nitrogen oxides. Selective catalytic reduction (SCR) of NOx with NH3 is the mainstream technology of the treatment for NOx emissions at present. The added NH3 is able to reduce NOx to N2 and H2O in the presence of excess oxygen [2,3]. V2O5-WO3(MO3)/TiO2 is currently the most common commercial catalyst due to its good catalytic activity and high resistance to sulfur dioxide [4]. But the narrow operation temperature (300–400°C) and the potential hazards caused by the loss of V2O5 are main disadvantages for it. As an abundant, inexpensive and nontoxic material, cerium oxides have shown applications in solid oxide fuel cells, oxygen storage capacitors, and the three way catalyst (TWC) of which are used for gasoline engine emission control [5,6]. Because of the redox shift between Ce4+ and Ce3+ under oxidizing and reducing conditions [7], it has unique performance to store&release oxygen. This is favorable to the oxidation of NO to NO2, which makes it widely used in SCR reaction either as a promoter or as an active center. As a promoter, studies reported that the addition of Ce significantly improved the low temperature SCR performance of Mn/TiO2 [8,9], V-W/TiO2 [10], Cu/TiO2 [11], Cu-SAPO-34 monolith catalyst [12], etc. These studies all mentioned that the improvement was based on the increase of chemisorbed oxygen and acidity after Ce doping, and well dispersion of active species as well. Some works also pointed out the Ce loaded TiO2 catalyst or amorphous Ce-Ti itself could obtain excellent NH3-SCR activity, which is attributed to the advantages in reduction state Ce3+, abundant acid sites and the chemisorption oxygen in the lattice [13–15]. We focused on the amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst in our previously work [16], and found a remarkably increase in SCR efficiency at low temperature by doping non-metal (fluorine) into amorphous ceria-titania catalyst. It was confirmed that the improvement was related to the increase in oxygen vacancy, chemisorbed oxygen, acid sites and NO adsorption species [17]. Other than this, reducing atmosphere pretreatment was commonly used to strengthen the activities for metal oxide catalysts by reducing the valence state of the active species and producing more surface defects, especially oxygen vacancies [18–20]. These positive influences by pretreatment could also be favorable to the performance of Ce-Ti catalyst in SCR reaction, which has not been researched so far. In previous research, we found that H2 pretreatment on Ce-Ti could indeed display a promoting effect for NH3-SCR, which attracted our interest. In this study, we prepared a ceria-titania (designated as Ce-Ti) catalyst by co-precipitation method and pretreated it by H2-N2 mixed flow. Several characterization such as XRD, PL, H2-TPR, XPS, Raman, TPD and in-situ DRIFT were carried out to help us find out the properties difference caused by the pretreatment. This paper would offer a possibility of further modification and application for amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The Ce-Ti catalyst was prepared by a co-precipitation method, which had been reported in our previous manuscript [16], the molar ratio of Ce/Ti for catalyst is 0.3. To obtain the H2-pretreat catalyst, pretreatment was performed in a U-tube quartz reactor. The Ce-Ti was first purged with N2 stream at 120°C for 0.5h, then pretreated with 50mL/min H2 +N2 mixed gas at different temperature for hours, in which the H2 was 1v%. The resultant was designated as xCe-Ti/H-y, of which x means the pretreat period (xh) whereas y stands for the pretreat temperature (y°C) for catalysts. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was recorded on a XD-3 diffractometer (Bruker D8 ADVANCE, Germany) using Cu Kα radiation (λ=0.l5406nm) at room temperature in the 2θ ranging from 5° to 50°. The surface atomic composition and chemical environment were characterized by the X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using a PHI Quantera II (ULVAC-PHI, Japan) XPS System equipped monochromatic Al-Kα excitation. All the binding energy values were calibrated by using C1s peak at 284.8eV as a reference. Oxygen vacancies were analyzed by photoluminescence (PL) spectra at room temperature using a Labram-HR800-type spectro-photometer (Jobin Yvon CO., France) with a He-Cd laser (λ=325nm) as the light source. Raman spectra were recorded on a Renishaw Invia Raman Microscope with Ar+ radiation (514nm). The laser light was focused on the samples by using a microscope equipped with an ×50 objective lens. Temperature Programmed Desorption of Nitric Oxide (NO-TPD) or Ammonia (NH3-TPD) and Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) were carried out in a quartz U-tube reactor on an automated chemisorption analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) by the GC method. Before the measurements, each 100mg catalyst was pretreated in the He stream at 50mL/min from room temperature to 300°C to purge the surface and the furnace temperature was lowered to 50°C. For TPD, the catalyst was then saturated with NO or NH3 (1% in N2) at a flow rate of 50mL/min for 1h, the measurement was taken from 50 up to 700°C at 10°C/min under 50mL/min He. H2-TPR was performed by heating the catalyst from 50°C to 700°C at 10°C/min under 50mL/min H2–N2 mixture gas (10% H2, v/v). All signal was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). In-situ Diffused reflectance infrared Fourier transform (DRIFT) spectroscopy experiments were carried out by a Nicolet IZ10 FTIR spectrometer, equipped with a liquid-nitrogen-cooled MCT detector. 32 scans were averaged for each spectrum, which were recorded at a resolution of 4cm−1. Prior to each experiment, background was taken by recording the IR spectrum of KBr in a N2 stream at 240°C, and had been deducted for each spectrum. The samples were then pretreated in the in-situ cell at 400°C in a flow of N2 for 30min to remove any adsorbed species. During the experiment, NO, O2 and NH3 were fed into N2 flow when required, the spectrum and response time was recorded when surface species changed or eventually stabilized. 2.3 Catalytic test The activities test of NH3-SCR were carried out at 120–390°C in a fixed-bed flow reactor (inner diameter 7mm) using 300mg catalyst with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 48,000h−1. The feed gas mixture contained 500ppm NO, 500ppm NH3, 5% O2, and N2 as a balance with a total flow rate of 150mL/min. Concentration of N2O, NO and NO2 were analyzed in a Servopro 4900 analyzer, and NOx was calculated by adding N2O, NO and NO2. The NOX conversion is defined as: X = N O x i n − N O x o u t N O x i n × 100 % 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalytic performance Fig. 1 shows the NOx conversion of catalysts from 120 to 390°C. From Fig. 1(a), the SCR catalytic performance substantially increased in the following order: Ce-Ti<3Ce-Ti/H-500<3Ce-Ti/H-300<3Ce-Ti/H-400. For all catalysts, the NOx conversion increased with temperature at low temperature range (120–240°C). The unpretreated Ce-Ti show the lowest NOx conversion among catalysts, which reached 58.8%, 77.2% and 81.4% at 180, 210 and 240°C, then rapidly dropped. The catalytic performance improved within the temperature range after Ce-Ti was pretreated in the mixed gas at 300°C for 3h. The NOx conversion could reach 90.5% and 92.3% at 240 and 270°C, which verified a benefit effect by pretreatment. 3Ce-Ti/H-400 sample demonstrated the best activity and widest temperature window in all catalysts we tested, the NOx conversion was above 95% from 210°C to 360°C, which still remained 88.9% at 390°C. In comparison with 3Ce-Ti/H-400, the activity obviously declined when the pretreatment temperature rose to 500°C. The NOx conversion at high temperature range (above 300°C) was even lower than 3Ce-Ti/H-300. This would be caused by the destruction of amorphous form and formation of crystalline by higher pretreatment temperature, which would decrease the catalytic activity. The results indicated that H2-pretreatment could promote favorable effects on SCR activity and broad its operating temperature window, and 400°C was the optimum pretreatment temperature for Ce-Ti catalyst. Fig. 1(b) displays the NOx conversion of samples with different pretreatment period at the most efficient temperature of 400°C. The NOx conversion for Ce-Ti was already improved after 2h pretreatment. Compared to the 2Ce-Ti/H-400, a notable raise was observed on the catalysts with at least one more hour pretreatment, which means that 2h pretreatment was insufficient to fully activating the catalyst. Fig. 1(b) also presented that when the pretreatment time reached 3h, it was difficult to impact the activity of catalyst by lengthening the pretreatment period. Based on the active results above, we concluded that 3h and 400°C were the most suitable and efficient pretreatment conditions. The such obtained 3Ce-Ti/H-400 was further characterized and analyzed to identify the reasons for the enhancement. For brevity, the 3Ce-Ti/H-400 will be marked as Ce-Ti/H in the ensuing discussion. 3.2 Catalysts characterization 3.2.1 XRD results XRD measurement was performed to explore the polymorphs and possible structural changes for catalysts, the results are shown in Fig. 2 . Only the presence of a weak broad peak at 2θ=19–36° was detected, which proved the ceria and titania were displayed in amorphous state for all catalysts [21]. No distinct peak belonging to the phase of Anatase TiO2 (PDF#21-1272) or Cerianite CeO2 (PDF#34-0394) was clearly observed. According to the essays [21,22], the amorphous state was beneficial to the SCR reaction, which might be caused by the Ce/Ti ratio we selected. The XRD pattern was not significantly changed after hydrogen pretreatment, this proved that it did not apparently affect the state or generate new polymorph for Ce-Ti catalyst. 3.2.2 PL analysis PL emission is generally used to detect the surface defects (mainly oxygen vacancies in this study), which acts as electron-trapping center. As shown in Fig. 3 , both Ce-Ti and Ce-Ti/H display a notable PL signal with some differences. Peak 1 at about 535nm was assigned to the oxygen vacancy with one trapped electron, and Peak 2 at 630nm might be a consequence of the polarizability of the lattice ions surrounding the vacancy [23,24]. The intensity for Ce-Ti was increased after H2-pretreatment to gain Ce-Ti/H. According to our previous study [25], the increase was caused by the reduction of Ce-O-Ti link bonds and the descending of interaction between Ce and Ti. This reduction results in a greater amount of surface defects and heavier peak intensity of Ce-Ti/H catalyst. As oxygen vacancies were the main surface defects for Ce-Ti catalyst, the pretreatment leads to more oxygen vacancies. Normally, more oxygen vacancies bring about more chemical adsorption oxygen, the XPS spectra of O 1s would further verify this conclusion. 3.2.3 H2-TPR analysis H2-TPR analysis was conducted to verify the reduction ability of Ce-Ti and Ce-Ti/H catalysts. Two main reduction peaks located at around 350°C and 550°C were distinguished for catalysts in Fig. 4 . Due to the stability of titania at the H2-TPR temperature range, the two peaks were mainly caused by the reduction of ceria. The first peak could be attributed to the reduction of the surface oxygen of ceria [26], and the peak area in Ce-Ti/H was smaller than that in Ce-Ti. Combined with PL result, some of the surface oxygen of ceria in the catalyst was reduced and converted to oxygen vacancies during the pretreatment, thus the H2 consumption was made less in the pretreated catalyst. The second peak arose from the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ in the catalyst body [27]. The reduction temperature for Ce-Ti/H was 50°C lower than that for Ce-Ti, and the hydrogen consumption for Ce-Ti/H was also lower. This fact suggested that the action of titanium on cerium was weakened due to the pretreatment, which perfectly verified the previous PL conclusion. Besides, some Ce4+ had already transferred to Ce3+ in the pretreatment. 3.2.4 XPS results XPS was conducted to test the chemical state in the near-surface region. Fig. 5 displays the XPS spectra of Ti 2p, Ce 3d and O 1s for samples, also the surface atomic concentrations are calculated and summarized in Table 1 . Fig. 5(a) shows the Ti 2p profiles for Ce-Ti and Ce-Ti/H. It can be found that the Ti in all catalysts stay in oxidation state of Ti4+. Compared to the standard peak position of TiO2, a shift to lower energy was found for both, which may be generated by the lower electronegativity of Ce compared to Ti [28]. Unlike the shift to higher binding energy of Ti which caused by F dopping we found before [29], the Ti spectra of Ce-Ti/H show a move to lower binding energy than Ce-Ti. It verified the descending of the interaction between Ce and Ti which proved by PL and TPR, thus less electron was transferred from titania to ceria than Ce-Ti. From the Ce 3d spectra in Fig. 5(b), two multipliers for all catalysts can be found after fitting. The bands labeled u, u”, u”’, v, v”, and v”’ represented the 3d104f0 spin-orbit of Ce4+ states, whereas the u’, v’ bands was assigned to the 3d104f1 spin-orbit of Ce3+ ions [30]. The spin-orbit splitting of Ce 3d5/2 and Ce 3d3/2 was 18.5eV for all the catalysts, which was in good agreement with standard value. It could be clearly seen that a mixture of Ce3+/Ce4+ oxidation state existed on the surface of the catalysts, which suggests that the catalyst surfaces are not fully oxidized. As obtained before, the Ce3+ concentration was low in the pure CeO2. Therefore the influence of titanium on cerium could bring about oxygen vacancies, due to the fact that electron-trapping effect of oxygen vacancies electrons were trapped by Ce4+ to form Ce3+. It can also be concluded from Table 1 that the ratio of Ce3+ peaks was higher in Ce-Ti/H (%) than that in the un-pretreated Ce-Ti (%). The pretreatment had a strong reduction effect on the surface Ce4+ to Ce3+, and produced more oxygen vacancies simultaneously, which was consistent with the PL and H2-TPR results. The XPS spectra of O 1s are presented in Fig. 5(c), the spectrum was divided into two distinct peaks, which designated the existence of two surface oxygen species on the catalysts. The peak with binding energy at 530.0eV could be ascribed to the lattice oxygen (denoted as Oβ), and the higher binding energy peak at 531.6eV was attributed to the chemisorbed oxygen (denoted as Oα) [31]. Based on the area integral of the O 1s spectra, the relative concentration ratio of Oα/(Oα+Oβ) was shown in Table 1. As can be obtained from the table that Ce-Ti/H displayed a higher Oα/(Oα+Oβ) ratio of 0.50, for which Ce-Ti was 0.39. This result show that the pretreatment led to the enhancement on the formation of chemisorbed oxygen species. Combined with the result of Ce 3d and the previously analysis, the growth of chemisorbed oxygen species was attributed to the increasing of vacancies and unsaturated bonds, which was mostly associated with the transform of Ce4+ to Ce3+. It is reported that chemisorbed oxygen is one of the most active oxygen and has played a key role in the oxidation of NO to NO2 [32]. NO2 is easier to form nitrate and react with the adsorbed NH3 on Lewis acid sites or the NH4 + on Brønstred acid sites, which has finally improved the NO conversion of NH3-SCR. 3.2.5 Raman analysis Raman analysis (Fig. 6 ) was used to gain further insight into the structure of nanocrystals. As presented in Fig. 6, no peak related to CeO2 compound was detected, four main peaks at about 135, 173, 354 and 545cm−1 were observed, the peak at 135cm−1 was corresponding to anatase phase TiO2, and the 173, 354 and 545cm−1 peaks were belonging to brannerite-structured CeTi2O6 [33]. After the pretreatment, the peak of TiO2 was slightly enhanced, and the three CeTi2O6 peaks were much weaker than the Ce/Ti sample. Taking into account the strong interaction between Ce and Ti, the pretreatment might have affected the Ce-O-Ti structure, and the oxygen at Ce site was released and the oxygen vacancies generated. Therefore the Ce in CeTi2O6 was converted to active Ce species and the Ti tended to recompose as Ti-O-Ti structure. Moreover, an important peak at 1110cm−1 which was assigned to the superoxide ions (O2 −) in chemisorbed oxygen appeared at Ce/Ti-H [34]. As a result of the pretreatment, lower valence Ce and superoxide ions were produced, which was consistent with XPS results. The superoxide ions can promote the NO oxidate to NO2 and nitrate groups which lead to the enhancement in the SCR activity. 3.3 Oxidation and adsorption 3.3.1 NO oxidation and adsorption properties The NO oxidation and adsorption properties for catalysts were shown in Fig. 7 . At the temperature range from 50 to 700°C, NO desorption peaks were observed and the desorption was completed at below 700°C over all catalysts. It can be seen from Fig. 7(a) that the desorption peak at low-temperature range was due to weakly adsorbed NO, and the high-temperature peaks were assigned to the strongly adsorbed species (e.g., NO2, nitrate) [35,36]. The intensity of NO desorption peaks, particularly at the strongly adsorbed sites for Ce-Ti/H was significantly higher than Ce-Ti. Based on the NO oxidation test from Fig. 7(b) at 180°C, the NO conversion to NO2 was only 2.2% for Ce-Ti, and it was slightly increased to about 12% for Ce-Ti/H. The NO conversion to NO2 was 5.7% for Ce-Ti and 18.6% for Ce-Ti/H at 240°C. These indicated that the pretreatment strengthened the oxidation capability of catalyst, and the oxidation ability increased with a rising temperature, which was coincided with the active test. The NO-TPD and oxidation test demonstrated that the pretreatment can promote the NO oxidation and adsorption properties for Ce-Ti catalyst. Combined with the Raman results, these promotion effects were mainly due to the generation of superoxide ions during the pretreatment. 3.3.2 NH3 adsorption and acid sites The strength and number of acid sites as well as the effect of pretreatment on acid sites which affect the NH3-SCR activity were determined by NH3-TPD (Fig. 8 ). In the temperature range we tested, three ammonia desorption peaks from strong acid sites (above 600°C), moderate acid sites (from 400 to 500°C) and weak acid sites (from 150 to 250°C) were observed for all catalysts [37]. For Ce-Ti, the weak acid sites was attributed to weak Brönsted acid sites and the moderate acid sites was assigned to Lewis acid sites [38]. It could be seen from Fig. 4 that both Brönsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites in Ce-Ti/H were more than those in Ce-Ti. The pretreatment brought about a large number of acid sites over Ce-Ti, especially the lewis acid sites. As previously presented by XPS results, the enhancement might be associated with the increase in chemisorbed oxygen species [39], which would be favorable for the catalytic activity in SCR reaction. 3.4 In-situ DRIFT study Fig. 9 shows the in-situ DRIFT results of the reaction among NO, O2, NH3 on (a) Ce-Ti and (b) Ce-Ti/H catalysts at 240°C. Stable spectrum of each sample was taken in a flow of 50mL/minN2 at 240°C as a comparison (labeled as Ce-Ti or Ce-Ti/H). First step (labeled as 1)), 500ppm of NO and 5% of O2 were introduced in N2 flow. Wait until the adsorbed species to stabilize, then 500ppm NH3 was added in the NO-O2-N2 mixture (labeled as 2)). From Fig. 9(a), as NO and O2 introduced in N2 flow, a series of weak bands around 1521cm−1 to 1577cm−1 were recorded for Ce-Ti, which was attributed to bidentate nitrates [40]. Those bands could reach saturation within 10min, but it could not increase significantly with an extra adsorption for 15min. For Ce-Ti/H, the bidentate nitrates around 1525cm−1 to 1581cm−1 were saturated after 25min adsorption. The bands intensity for Ce-Ti/H were stronger than that for Ce-Ti, proved better adsorption of NO by H2-pretreatment, which was consistent with NO-TPD results. Moreover, a new band at 1612cm−1 which was assigned to adsorbed NO2 species was detected on Ce-Ti/H [41], and this could be the evidence of easily oxidation of NO on Ce-Ti/H. As 500ppm NH3 added in the flow, variations of bands were found on both catalysts. There was no significant change for Ce-Ti within the first five minutes. The bidentate nitrates were almost disappeared and new bands arose at 1448, 3126, 3773 and 3485cm−1 after 25min. The band at 1448cm−1 is due to the asymmetric bending vibrations of NH4+ [42], whereas bands above 3000cm−1 region are stretching vibration of NH [43]. These bands were stabilized in 45min after the introduction of NH3. For Ce-Ti/H, the reaction between NH3 and NO species was relatively faster. The intensity of adsorbed NO2 began to decline within 5min, the disappearance of bidentate nitrates as well as NO2 and the formation of NH3 species was recorded in 15min. The eventually steady time of these bands was 25min, which suggested a quicker response of NH3 at Ce-Ti/H catalyst than Ce-Ti. In addition, when NO and NH3 were present in the gas flow simultaneously, the surface was covered mainly by the NH3 related species. This suggests that adsorption of NH3 was dominant under the SCR reaction conditions [44]. 3.5 Durability and stability Further more, catalytic durability and the resistance of water vapor and sulfur dioxide of Ce-Ti/H catalyst were also tested. As shown in Fig. 10 (a), a 72-h stability test was taken to investigate the catalytic durability at 240°C. The NOx conversion remained stable at nearly 100% for this catalyst, and it did not show a significant deactivation within 72h at 240°C. After that, three “cooling and heating” cycle tests from 120 to 240°C were conducted, the NOx conversion was recorded at each test point when stabilized. Dashed lines in Fig. 10(a) represented the original data of Ce-Ti/H at each temperature in Fig. 1, there was not much difference (less than 3%) between the cycle test results and the original data. This indicates that the enhancement created by pretreatment can be fully maintained. The Ce-Ti/H catalyst has a good durability in NH3-SCR reaction. Fig. 10(b) displays the effect of H2O and SO2 on the NOx conversion at 240°C for Ce-Ti and Ce-Ti/H. For Ce-Ti/H, the NOx conversion changed from 100% to 85% when 2 v% H2O was introduced into the system. And it was further declined to about 78.5% after the water vapor content increased to 4 v%. However, adding 2 v% and 4 v% H2O caused a reduction of 12% and 4% in NOx conversion for Ce-Ti, which was slightly lower than that for Ce-Ti/H. This inhibition is generally attributed to the competitive adsorption between H2O and the reactant [45]. The NOx conversion could recovered rapidly when the H2O was switched off. When 200ppm SO2 was added, the NOx conversion continued to decrease and eventually stabilized, the Ce-Ti/H decreased by 13.4%, and the descent for Ce-Ti was 10.3%. The activity could not be completely recovered after SO2 was cutting off for a period of time, there was still 3–5% of NOx conversion unrecoverable for the two catalysts. Thus the SO2 could have a poisonous effect on the catalyst, in addition to the competitive adsorption effect, which might be ascribed to the formation of ammonium sulfate [46]. The two catalysts show similar inhibition effects caused by H2O and SO2. The existence of H2O displayed an apparent and quick inhibition of the catalysts, which could be fully restored. The SO2 demonstrated a slow inactivation effect for catalysts, and the deactivation was partly unrecoverable. What’s more, the competitive adsorption and poisonous effect should occur at the surface oxygen vacancies, therefore the activity declined more obviously on Ce-Ti/H than on Ce-Ti. The specific influences of H2O and SO2 on the catalyst and detailed reasons of deactivation demand further research. 4 Conclusion Amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst was prepared by a co-precipitation method, and H2-pretreatment was carried out to enhance the NH3-SCR activity for it. The activity result concluded that 3h and 400°C were the most suitable and efficient pretreatment conditions, the NOx conversion was above 95% from 210°C to 360°C for such pretreated catalyst. XRD result had confirmed the existence of amorphous state for catalysts, and the pretreatment did not apparently affect the state or generate new polymorph. Through PL, H2-TPR, XPS and Raman analyses, the pretreatment brought about a decrease of Ce-O-Ti link bonds and descent the of interaction between Ce and Ti, part of Ce4+ was also reduced to active Ce3+. These led to more oxygen vacancies, which could generate more chemisorbed oxygen. The superoxide ions was detected for Ce-Ti/H catalyst by Raman, NO-TPD and oxidation test verified the promotional effect of pretreatment in the NO adsorption and oxidation. NH3-TPD result indicated that the pretreatment could bring about added number of acid sites over Ce-Ti, especially the lewis acid sites. All these should be the reasons for the enhancement in Ce-Ti catalyst by H2-pretreatment. The in-situ DRIFT study show better adsorption of NO and quicker response of NH3 by H2-pretreatment, which were consistent with the previous conclusions. The adsorption of NH3 was dominant under the SCR reaction conditions. In addition, the enhancement effects broguht about by H2-pretreatment on catalyst show good sustainability. Meanwhile the resistance of water vapor and sulfur dioxide were also evaluated. H2O demonstrated a quickly and recoverable inhibition, whereas SO2 had a slow inactivation effect which was partly unrecoverable. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen pretreatment was processed on the amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst which notably enhanced its NH3-SCR performance. We concluded that 3-h and 400°C were the most suitable and efficient pretreatment conditions, whereas the NOx conversion rate was above 95% from 210°C to 360°C for such pretreated catalyst. XRD, PL, H2-TPR, XPS and Raman analyses found that the enhancement was attributed to the effects generated by the pretreatment: Ce4+ reduced to active Ce3+, the incerase of the oxygen vacancies, the chemisorbed oxygen, and the formation of superoxide ions. The NO adsorption oxidation capability, and the acid sites were also promoted by the pretreatment, which were favorable for the SCR reaction. The reaction among NO, O2 and NH3 on catalysts were studied by in-situ DRIFT. The adsorption of NH3 was dominant under the SCR reaction conditions The enhancement demonstrated good durability. The stability of catalyst under water vapor and sulfur dioxide were also tested.
coredata.dc:title: Enhanced NOx removal performance of amorphous Ce-Ti catalyst by hydrogen pretreatment
coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
